document.heading: Omnibus Alcoholic Beverage Regulation Amendment Act of 2016

To amend Title 25 of the District of Columbia Official Code to make amendments to the law regulating the sale, transportation, and consumption of alcoholic beverages, including to define a bed and breakfast and establish the requirements to permit one to serve alcohol, clarify the entities that can apply for a club license, define a full-service grocery store and establish the requirements to permit one to serve alcohol, to establish 2 new categories of off-premises licenses for entities that are not open to the public and that sell alcoholic beverages through the Internet only, to revise notice requirements for certain entities, to define and prohibit the sale of powdered alcohol, to require an owner or licensed manager of a retailer's, manufacturer's, or wholesaler's license to carry identification and to produce it upon request from an investigator with the Alcoholic Beverage Regulation Administration or a member of the Metropolitan Police Department, and to clarify that the prohibition against drinking an alcoholic beverage in a street, alley, park, sidewalk, or parking area does not apply to an event that is licensed by the Alcoholic Beverage Control Board.

history.summary: Law 21-260 makes various changes to the law concerning the sale, transportation, and regulation of alcoholic beverages. It also includes provisions creating a bed and beverage license, and making various changes to existing licenses.
history.committee: Committee on Committee of the Whole, Subcommittee on Local Business Development and Utilities

document.text: BE IT ENACTED BY THE COUNCIL OF THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA, That this act may be cited as the "Omnibus Alcoholic Beverage Regulation Amendment Act of 2016".

section.text: Title 25 of the District of Columbia Official Code is amended as follows:

Section 25-101 is amended as follows:
A new paragraph (9A) is added to read as follows:
"Bed and breakfast" means an establishment with fewer than 30 guest rooms, a dining room in the same or a connected building, and where breakfast is included in the price of a sleeping room.

Paragraph (15) is amended by striking the phrase "owning, leasing, or occupying a building" and inserting the phrase "a limited liability company, or partnership owning, leasing, or occupying a building" in its place.

para.text: A new paragraph (22A) is added to read as follows:

"Full-service grocery store" means a self-service retail establishment independently owned or part of a corporation operating a chain of retail establishments under the same trade name that is licensed as a grocery store under § 47-2827 that:
Offers for sale a full line of food products that includes at least 6 of the 7 following food categories:
Fresh fruits and vegetables;
Fresh and uncooked meats, poultry, and seafood;
Dairy products;
Canned foods;
Frozen foods;
Dry groceries and baked goods; or
Non-alcoholic beverages;
May include related service departments, such as a bakery, pharmacy, or florist, or departments that offer household products or sundries; and
Has a minimum of 50% of the store's square footage of selling area dedicated to the sale of the food categories listed in subparagraph (A) of this paragraph; or
Has a minimum of 6,000 square feet of the store's selling area dedicated to the sale of the food categories listed in subparagraph (A) of this paragraph; and
Sets aside a minimum of 5% of the store's selling area dedicated for the sale of the food items listed in subparagraph (A) of this paragraph.

For the purposes of this subparagraph, the term "selling area" means the area in a retail establishment that is open to the public. The term "selling area" does not include storage areas, preparation areas, or rest rooms.

para.text: Subsection (d) is amended to read as follows:
There shall be 4 classes of off-premises retailer's licenses:
A retailer's license, class A, shall authorize a licensee to sell spirits, beer, and wine.
A retailer's license, class B, shall authorize a licensee to sell beer and wine.
A retailer's license, class IA, shall authorize a licensee that only operates as an Internet retailer and does not have a physical location open to the public to sell spirits, beer, and wine.
A retailer's license, class IB, shall authorize a licensee that only operates as an Internet retailer and does not have a physical location open to the public to sell beer and wine.

At the next class A retailer's license renewal, the Board shall convert an existing Internet off-premises retailer that does not have a physical location open to the public to one of the 2 new Internet retailer license categories, as described in paragraph 1(C) and (D) of this subsection.
A new subsection (d-1) is added to read as follows:

Notwithstanding any other provision or restriction in this title, the holder of a class B retailer's license located inside of a hotel with no public access to the street or the outside of the hotel's building may sell single containers of beer, malt liquor, or ale, excluding miniatures, in sizes of 70 ounces or less.
Section 25-113 is amended as follows:
Subsection (a) is amended by adding a new paragraph (5) to read as follows:

Except as provided in subparagraph (B) of this paragraph, a licensee of an on-premises retailer's license, class C or D, shall not purchase alcoholic beverages from an off-premises retailer's license, class A or B.

The licensee of an on-premises retailer's license, class C or D, may purchase alcoholic beverages from an off-premises retailer's license, class A, on Saturday, Sunday, or holiday during the hours when licensees under a wholesaler's license are closed.
Subsection (f)(2) is amended to read as follows:
No license shall be issued to a club that has not been incorporated for at least 3 months immediately before the filing of an application for the license.
A new subsection (k) is added to read as follows:
A bed and breakfast license shall be issued to a bed and breakfast that serves food only to registered guests, and their guests.

The license shall allow the service of alcoholic beverages to registered guests, and their guests, only for on-premises consumption in their private rooms or in the dining room, lounge, banquet hall, or other similar facility on the licensed premises.
The cost of alcoholic beverages served to registered guests, and their guests, shall be included by the licensee in the registered guest's room fee or with the cost of a meal.
There shall be 2 classes of bed and breakfast licenses:
Class C/B (spirits, beer, and wine); and
Class D/B (beer and wine).

para.text: New subsections (f), (g), and (h) are added to read as follows:

The holder of a wholesaler's license, class A, may utilize a portion of the licensed premises for the sampling of beer, wine, and spirits, and the holder of a wholesaler's license, class B, may utilize a portion of the licensed premises for the sampling of beer, during its approved hours of operation.
Wholesaler tastings shall:
Not be open to the public;
Be for the purpose of educating staff and introducing products to licensees: and
Be limited to the following:
Retailers;
Manufacturers;
Temporary and festival license holders;
Solicitors; and
Wholesaler staff.

The Board may approve the holder of a wholesaler's license, class A or B, that has obtained a tasting permit for its licensed premises to conduct tastings not open to the public at a designated common area of a storage facility where the wholesaler is a tenant.
The Board may issue a tasting permit to a private collector to conduct tastings not open to the public at a designated common area of a storage facility where the private collector is a tenant.
For the purposes of this section, the term "storage facility" means a bonded warehouse in the District of Columbia licensed by the Board for the storage of alcoholic beverages.

para.text: A new subsection (g) is added to read as follows:

In determining whether a licensee has a prior violation for the purposes of subsection (f) of this section, the 4-year period is the 4 years immediately preceding the date of the incident or conduct in the case pending before the Board for which the licensee has been found liable of violating subsection (a), (b), or (c) of this section, either by an order of the Board, the Board's acceptance of an offer-in-compromise, or the licensee's payment of a fine.

A prior violation falls within the 4-year period if the date that the licensee was found liable of violating subsection (a), (b), or (c) of this section, either by an order of the Board, the Board's acceptance of an offer-in-compromise, or the licensee's payment of a fine, falls within the 4-year period.

para.text: New sections 25-833, 25-834, and 25-835 are added to read as follows:

section.heading: Tampering or refilling bottles.
section.text: A licensee or the licensee's employees shall not knowingly:

para.text: Misrepresent the brand of any alcoholic beverage sold or offered for sale;
Keep any alcoholic beverage other than in the bottle or container in which it was purchased;
Refill or partly refill any bottle or container of an alcoholic beverage;
Dilute or otherwise tamper with the contents of any bottle or container of an alcoholic beverage;
Remove or obliterate any label, mark, or stamp affixed to any bottle or container of an alcoholic beverage offered for sale; or
Deliver or sell the contents of any bottle or container of an alcoholic beverage that has had the label, mark, or stamp on it removed or obliterated.
It shall be unlawful for a person to sell or offer to sell powdered alcohol.
A licensee under either an on-premises or off-premises retailer's license shall not offer for sale powdered alcohol to a customer.
A person who violates this section shall be fined an amount of up to a maximum of $1,000.

It shall be unlawful for a person to willfully or knowingly alter, forge, counterfeit, or endorse a document, or make use of any false or misleading document, reasonably calculated to deceive the public as being a genuine license issued by ABRA.

It shall be unlawful for a person to willfully or knowingly furnish to a member of the Metropolitan Police Department ("MPD") or an ABRA investigator an altered, forged, counterfeited, endorsed, or false or misleading document reasonably calculated to deceive MPD or the ABRA investigator as being a genuine license issued by ABRA.
A person convicted of a violation of this section shall be fined no more than the amount set forthin § 22-3571.01, or incarcerated for no more than one year, or both.
